question.stem: The corrective actions made by the bionic pancreas on a regular basis in response to changing blood sugar levels are similar to which natural biological process?

choices.text: a feedback mechanism
an immune response
biochemical digestion
ATP production

para: In addition, the pancreas regulates the production and release of insulin in response to the blood sugar level. Type I diabetes involves an unwanted immune system response which targets cells in the pancreas which produce insulin, a hormone vital to the control of blood sugar levels. (Insulin is a naturally occurring hormone released by the pancreas in response to increased blood sugar levels. It is know that obese people are resistant to the action of their own insulin, a hormone that is released from the pancreas in response to increased levels of sugar in the blood. This type of ion channel — called an ATP-sensitive potasium channel — is known to be a key component in the process by which the pancreas secretes insulin in response to increased blood sugar levels. The pancreas' response to rising blood sugar levels is a negative control response. Pancreas As previously mentioned, the pancreas is responsible for regulating blood sugar levels. Almost all of the "missing million" will be suffering from type II diabetes, in which the body's natural mechanisms for regulating levels of sugar in the blood - normally controlled by insulin produced in the pancreas - become overwhelmed, usually because of obesity. Pancreas The pancreas is a gland which makes insulin, needed to control blood sugar levels, and enzymes needed for digestion of food. The pancreas is responsible for insulin production in the body, which controls levels of blood sugar.

question.stem: During periods of vigorous physical activity, a person’s breathing and heart rates increase. This enables the cells of the body to perform more efficiently because it helps the cells to

store excess glucose in muscles
reduce the amount of ATP produced
convert more oxygen to glucose

para: This helps the oxygen to be more efficiently transported to cells around the body. In addition, when we work hard, our breathing rate increases because we need to get more oxygen from the air to the working cells, and each of those breaths is carrying precious moisture out of the body. Antioxidants allow cells to perform more efficiently on less oxygen, enabling sufficient oxygen to be utilized for the cells and organs that specifically need it. Heart beat rate, breathing rate, and the production of red blood cells, which carry oxygen throughout the body, increases as the body acclimates to high altitude allowing more oxygen to be "grabbed" from every breath. Your body adapts to increases in altitude by changing your breathing pattern and heart rate levels and by producing more oxygen carrying red blood cells.
